author: Lucy Meakin
title: Bond Gains Send Italy’s Yield Below 2% as Repaid Cash Seeks Home
text:
Euro-area government bonds advanced, sending Italy’s 10-year yield below 2 percent for the first time in more than six weeks, as investors sought to reinvest funds from redemption and coupon payments.
With bond investors due to receive about 41 billion euros ($45 billion) of bond redemptions in Austria, the Netherlands and Italy this week, securities climbed across the region. Spanish 10-year bonds rose for a seventh day, the longest run of gains since August, as traders looked beyond political turmoil in Greece.
“The key explanatory factor is really the huge reinvestment needs of investors this month,” said Michael Leister, a senior rates strategist at Commerzbank AG in Frankfurt. “In July we have more than 100 billion euros in redemptions and coupon payments and these will have to be recycled. With market liquidity still being a bit patchy, the price impact of this recycling seems to be stronger than usual.”
Italy’s 10-year bond yield fell eight basis points, or 0.08 percentage points, to 1.99 percent at 11:20 a.m. London time. The 1.5 percent security due in June 2025 climbed 0.675, or 6.75 euros per 1,000-euro face amount, to 95.725.
Spanish 10-year yields fell eight basis points to 2.01 percent, adding to a 28 basis-point decline over the previous six days.
The average yield on euro-area sovereign securities declined to the lowest since June 4 on Tuesday as investors sought new homes for their cash. The yield was at 0.97 percent, Bank of America Merrill Lynch indexes show, after touching its 2015 high of 1.08 percent as recently as June 15.
